In Julia, Write a function `ispersonal` that returns a trait if the provided Vehicle type is a personal vehicle for everyday driving. All vehicles are subtypes of AbstractVehicle. Function must work for types: Car, Motorcycle, Bus, Truck. The first two should return true, the latter two should return false . The function should default to false for any other subtype of AbstractVehicle. Provide an example.

Here is how you can implement this in Julia:

```julia
abstract type AbstractVehicle end
struct Car <: AbstractVehicle; end
struct Motorcycle <: AbstractVehicle; end
struct Bus <: AbstractVehicle; end
struct Truck <: AbstractVehicle; end

ispersonal(::Type{Car}) = true
ispersonal(::Type{Motorcycle}) = true
ispersonal(::Type{Bus}) = false
ispersonal(::Type{Truck}) = false

# Default behavior
ispersonal(::Type{<:AbstractVehicle}) = false

function test()
    @test ispersonal(Car) == true
    @test ispersonal(Motorcycle) == true
    @test ispersonal(Bus) == false
    @test ispersonal(Truck) == false
end
```

In this code, we define an abstract type `AbstractVehicle` and four concrete types: `Car`, `Motorcycle`, `Bus`, and `Truck`. We then define a function `ispersonal` that takes a type as input. If the type is one of the concrete types `Car` or `Motorcycle`, it returns true, because these are personal vehicles. If the type is either `Bus` or `Truck`, it returns false, because these are not personal vehicles.

The default behavior for all other subtypes of `AbstractVehicle` is to return false, as specified by the last line in our function definition. We then test this function using a simple set of assertions in a new function called `test`.

Note: The `@test` macro will throw an error if any assertion fails, which can be helpful for debugging when you are writing tests.
